At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output.  \n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080][E\u2081][E\u2082]  Bell sources: [S\u2083\u2084] [S\u2085\u2086]  \n         \u2193  \n  Near-field scatterer (custom multiport)  \n         \u2193  \n  Outputs: [D\u2080:C\u2032][D\u2081:T\u2081\u2032][D\u2082:T\u2082\u2032][D\u2083][D\u2084][D\u2085][D\u2086]  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cHeralded Fredkin gate via near-field scattering multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cpair_sources\u201d: [[3,4],[5,6]]  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the existing heralded Fredkin primitive\u2014see \u201cHeralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\u201d\u2014with only an alternative multiport realization. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new mechanism or capability beyond re-implementing the same controlled-SWAP.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a quantum-network primitive (avoiding pure state generation):\n    1. A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. By post-selecting on a fixed pattern of Bell outcomes and contrasting clockwise versus counterclockwise traversal, we directly reveal a non-commuting (non-Abelian) Wilson-loop effect in a purely linear-optical quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Anomalous Floquet Entanglement Pump on a 1D Photonic Ring\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We present a static linear-optical realization of the target \u201cAnomalous Floquet Entanglement Pump on a 1D Ring,\u201d in which two complementary heralded measurement outcomes implement alternating Bell-pair swaps on a ring of four photonic parties, thereby pumping entanglement chirally around the loop while the bulk remains disentangled. Our purely probabilistic scheme uses only photon-pair sources, ancillary detectors, and forbidden direct links between non-neighbours to demonstrate a chiral winding of entanglement\u2014an optical analog of an anomalous Floquet topological insulator.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources and post-selected Bell measurements perform preshared entanglement encoding at A, entanglement swapping at B/C, and decoding at D, heralding both correct qubit transmission and detection of single-photon loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output. The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposal implements a coherent superposition of teleportation channels to two receivers\u2014functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d (and closely related to \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d).     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Thermalization slowing down of weakly nonintegrable quantum spin\n  dynamics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Purcell enhancement of single-photon emitters in silicon\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Chiral Chaos Enhanced Sensing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"near field scattering\" and \"near field distribution\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that uses a multi-port near-field-like interferometer to coherently route entanglement between different distant pairs, creating a superposition of network topologies (i.e. a superposition of two different entanglement-swapping orders).\n    2. A parallel teleportation network in which two qubits are teleported simultaneously through a single near-field multi-mode \u201cbeam splitter\u201d device that implements two Bell measurements at once by scattering modes in the near field.\n    3. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. Pytheus can optimize ancilla-assisted Bell measurements via linear optics.\n    2. The parallel-teleportation idea is a direct extension of standard teleportation and uses only two simultaneous Bell measurements; it\u2019s certainly doable but less novel than a superposed routing.\n    3. No existing Pytheus design explores a superposition of different swap operations.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires: two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon ancilla emitter to control the effective near-field-like multi-port coupler, linear-optics elements (beam splitters, phase shifters) to build the central multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer,\u201d and number-resolving detectors. No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we are targeting an entanglement-swapping process, not raw state generation.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). A heralded linear-optical Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate realized by a near-field multiport \u201cscatterer,\u201d where the near-field distribution of modes (phase pattern) is controlled by the ancilla\u2019s path, effecting a conditional swap via teleportation\u2010inspired Bell measurements.\n 2. We are targeting a gate (network transformation), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded Photonic Fredkin Gate via Near-Field Scattering Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a probabilistic, heralded controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate on three unknown photonic qubits (control C, targets T\u2081 and T\u2082) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection, where the core interaction is a small \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport scatterer whose mode distribution is shaped by ancilla phase control.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Control photon C (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Target photon T\u2081 (mode 1)  \n   \u2013 E\u2082 \u2192 Target photon T\u2082 (mode 2)  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (Bell pairs):  \n   \u2013 S\u2083\u2084 emits ancilla photons a\u2083 (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 4)  \n   \u2013 S\u2085\u2086 emits ancilla photons a\u2085 (mode 5) & a\u2086 (mode 6)  \n\nAll seven photons are injected into a single linear-optics multiport network (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) consisting of beam-splitters and phase-shifters arranged to tightly bunch modes 0\u20266 in the near field. At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output.  \n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080][E\u2081][E\u2082]  Bell sources: [S\u2083\u2084] [S\u2085\u2086]  \n         \u2193  \n  Near-field scatterer (custom multiport)  \n         \u2193  \n  Outputs: [D\u2080:C\u2032][D\u2081:T\u2081\u2032][D\u2082:T\u2082\u2032][D\u2083][D\u2084][D\u2085][D\u2086]  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cHeralded Fredkin gate via near-field scattering multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cpair_sources\u201d: [[3,4],[5,6]]  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the existing heralded Fredkin primitive\u2014see \u201cHeralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\u201d\u2014with only an alternative multiport realization. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new mechanism or capability beyond re-implementing the same controlled-SWAP.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a quantum-network primitive (avoiding pure state generation):\n    1. A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new mechanism or capability beyond re\u2010implementing controlled, dual\u2010destination teleportation with a different interferometer.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus-compatible ways to marry near-field scattering and near-field distribution into a network primitive:  \n    1) A heralded Fredkin gate via a near-field scatterer,  \n    2) A coherent \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swap orders,  \n    3) Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation in one near-field multiport.  \n  Step 2: The Fredkin and swap-order ideas overlap too closely with known heralded-gate and \u201csuperposed swap\u201d proposals.  \n  Step 3: The bidirectional teleportation device is novel\u2014it performs two teleportations in parallel with one linear-optical near-field scatterer.  \n  Step 4: It\u2019s novel because no existing Pytheus design simultaneously teleports two unknown qubits in a single scattering network; it implements two Bell-measurements in one device.  \n  Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus since it uses only two single-photon emitters (unknown qubits), two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d), and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback, pure teleportation network.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSimultaneous Bidirectional Teleportation via Near-Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe teleport two unknown photonic qubits A and B to each other in one device. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives."
