Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method).     "output": "Here is a fresh Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network primitive that genuinely blends \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d with \u201cnear\u2010field distribution,\u201d avoids mere state generation, and poses a new foundational challenge:\n\n\u201cNetwork\u2010Topology Superposition via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d\n\n Explanation  \n We design a small linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) that, when fed with three Bell\u2010pair sources, can project onto a superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010swapping network topologies in one shot. Concretely, we want to entangle four distant modes A,B,C,D via two different swap orders\u2014(A\u2013X\u2192B\u2013Y\u2192C\u2013Z\u2192D) and (A\u2013Z\u2192B\u2013Y\u2192C\u2013X\u2192D)\u2014then post\u2010select their coherent superposition. This yields a superposition of two network\u2010graphs, not just two final states.\n\n Sources  \n  \u2022 Three probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources:  \n    S\u2081 emits into modes A (0)&X (3)  \n    S\u2082 emits into modes B (1)&Y (4)  \n    S\u2083 emits into modes C (2)&Z (5)  \n\n All six photons enter a single 6\u00d76 programmable multiport whose internal phases implement near\u2010field interference patterns.\n\n Detectors & Heralding  \n  \u2022 Four output \u201clogical\u201d modes at detectors D_A, D_B, D_C, D_D capture the end nodes A,B,C,D.  \n  \u2022 Two \u201cbridge\u201d detectors D\u2081,D\u2082 herald the two measured intermediate modes among {X,Y,Z}.  \n\n Protocol  \n 1. The multiport mixes all six modes.  \n 2. Conditioned on a specific two\u2010click pattern at D\u2081,D\u2082 (each registering exactly one photon), the device projects onto the coherent superposition of the two swap\u2010order graphs:  \n     (A\u2013X\u2192B\u2013Y\u2192C\u2013Z\u2192D) + (A\u2013Z\u2192B\u2013Y\u2192C\u2013X\u2192D).  \n 3. The four unmeasured photons now emerge at D_A\u2026D_D in a superposed network entanglement pattern.\n\n Pytheus Config Sketch  \n {  \n   \"description\": \"Network\u2010Topology Superposition via Near\u2010Field Multiport\",  \n   \"pair_sources\": [[0,3],[1,4],[2,5]],  \n   \"num_anc\": 2,                # detectors D\u2081,D\u2082  \n   \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # A,B,C,X,Y,Z  \n   \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2,5],      # A,B,C,D  \n   \"removed_connections\": [     # forbid direct EPR\u2192nonadjacent  \n     [0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4]  \n   ],  \n   \"number_resolving\": true,  \n   \"target_transformation\": [   # abstract graph\u2010superposition  \n     \"swap\u2010order\u20101\",  \n     \"swap\u2010order\u20102\"  \n   ]  \n }\n\n Why It\u2019s Novel  \n \u2022 No existing design superposes two full entanglement\u2010swap topologies in one device\u2014it goes beyond superposed single\u2010swap or teleportation channels.  \n \u2022 This is a superposition of network graphs (connectivity patterns), not just states.\n\n Why Pytheus Can Do It  \n \u2022 Uses only three probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and post\u2010selection\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s capability.  \n \u2022 No hyper\u2010entanglement, no dynamic feedback, and no cavities required.  \n \u2022 The abstract \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d simply instructs Pytheus to maximize overlap with the two swap\u2010order projections.\n\n Generalizations  \n \u2022 Extend to N\u2010node networks: superpose multiple routing graphs for programmable quantum internet primitives.  \n \u2022 Use higher\u2010dimensional EPR sources (qudits) for richer network\u2010graph superpositions.  \n\nThis network\u2010topology superposition experiment opens a new domain: coherent superpositions of entire quantum\u2010network layouts, directly blending near\u2010field scattering control with network\u2010graph distribution\u2014a conceptually fresh challenge for Pytheus and quantum\u2010network theory."
}

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that uses a multi-port near-field-like interferometer to coherently route entanglement between different distant pairs, creating a superposition of network topologies (i.e. a superposition of two different entanglement-swapping orders).\n    2. A parallel teleportation network in which two qubits are teleported simultaneously through a single near-field multi-mode \u201cbeam splitter\u201d device that implements two Bell measurements at once by scattering modes in the near field.\n    3. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. It is not pure state generation\u2014it\u2019s a process that yields a superposition of two different swap topologies. Pytheus can optimize ancilla-assisted Bell measurements via linear optics.\n    2. The parallel-teleportation idea is a direct extension of standard teleportation and uses only two simultaneous Bell measurements; it\u2019s certainly doable but less novel than a superposed routing.\n    3. A full d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding open problem; linear-optics schemes typically only get partial success. It might be too ambitious\u2014Pytheus may struggle to find a complete discrimination network without exotic interactions.\n  Step 3: Pick the most promising: the \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement routing.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement-swapping orders (i.e. two network topologies) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we are targeting an entanglement-swapping process, not raw state generation.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). Replacing the basis angle \u03b8 with a \u201cnear-field multiport\u201d control does not introduce a new primitive\u2014any universal multiport could already realize this continuous family. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new measurement resource or an unexpected performance advantage (e.g. loss-tolerance, non-Hermitian enhancement, topological protection) not reducible to a mere parameter sweep of a Bell analyzer.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cMulti-Outcome Entanglement-Swap Router via Near-Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to distribute entanglement from one \u201csource\u201d node A to any one of three remote \u201creceiver\u201d nodes R\u2081, R\u2082, R\u2083, using a single joint measurement on four photons in a compact near-field multiport (the \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d).  Upon one click out of four heralding detectors, A becomes entangled with exactly one R\u1d62.  By scaling the multiport this protocol generalizes to arbitrarily many receivers, opening a new primitive: a one\u2192N entanglement router.\n\n 1.  Sources  \n    \u2022  Bell pair S_A\u2013X prepares modes A (0) & X (1).  \n    \u2022  Bell pair S_Y\u2081\u2013R\u2081 prepares modes Y\u2081 (2) & R\u2081 (3).  \n    \u2022  Bell pair S_Y\u2082\u2013R\u2082 prepares modes Y\u2082 (4) & R\u2082 (5).  \n    \u2022  Bell pair S_Y\u2083\u2013R\u2083 prepares modes Y\u2083 (6) & R\u2083 (7).  \n\n 2.  Multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d)  \n    We inject the four \u201chalf-pairs\u201d X,Y\u2081,Y\u2082,Y\u2083 (modes 1,2,4,6) into a single 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam-splitters and phase-shifters whose internal layout mimics a sub-wavelength near-field scattering region.  The scattering matrix is chosen so that its four orthogonal joint-two-photon outputs project onto a 4-dimensional \u201cBell-like\u201d basis for modes (1,2,4,6).\n\n 3.  Detection & Heralding  \n    The four outputs of that scatterer feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084.  A click pattern with exactly one photon in detector D\u1d62 (and no photons in the other three) heralds the projection onto the i-th basis state.  Conditioned on D\u1d62, nodes A (mode 0) and R\u1d62 (mode 2i\u20131 \u2192 3,5 or 7) collapse into a two-qubit Bell state.\n\n 4.  Outputs  \n    \u2022  Photons at modes R\u2081 (3), R\u2082 (5), R\u2083 (7) are now entangled with A (0), but only the one corresponding to the triggered detector D\u1d62.  \n    \u2022  The other R\u2c7c (j\u2260i) photons are discarded or traced out.\n\nVisualization:  \n   Sources:   [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]   [4\u20135]   [6\u20137]  \n                \u2193      \u2193       \u2193       \u2193  \n            Near-field Scatterer (modes 1,2,4,6)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \n         Heralding Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n      Outputs: A(0)\u2013R\u1d62(3,5 or 7) entangled  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers (illustrative):  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"One\u2192Three entanglement router via near-field scatterer\",  \n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5],[6,7]],  \n  \"in_nodes\": [1,2,4,6],            # photons into the scatterer  \n  \"out_nodes\": [0,3,5,7],           # A & the three R\u1d62 modes  \n  \"num_anc\":       4,               # heralding detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084  \n  \"removed_connections\":[           # forbid direct ancilla\u2192wrong outputs  \n     [1,0],[2,0],[4,0],[6,0],  \n     [1,5],[1,7],[2,3],[2,7],  \n     [4,3],[4,7],[6,3],[6,5]  \n  ],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"target_measurement_basis\":[      # the four orthogonal projectors on modes (1,2,4,6)  \n    \"Bell\u2081\u208blike\",\"Bell\u2082\u208blike\",\"Bell\u2083\u208blike\",\"Bell\u2084\u208blike\"  \n  ]  \n}  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:  \n\u2022 No prior Pytheus design implements a single joint measurement that routes entanglement from one node to any one of N receivers in a single multiport.  All existing entanglement-swapping experiments swap exactly two pairs (N=1) or chain swaps; none realize a multi-outcome swap router.  \n\n\u2022 The use of a near-field scattering multiport to define a 4-outcome Bell-like measurement\u2014and thereby realize one\u2192N entanglement routing\u2014combines the physics of near-field distribution with quantum-network primitives in a fundamentally new way.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible for Pytheus:  \n\u2022 Only probabilistic Bell-pair sources and linear optics are used\u2014no cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\u2022 A single 4\u00d74 multiport (within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics toolkit) plus number-resolving heralding detectors implements the joint measurement.  \n\u2022 The idea is readily scalable: increase the multiport size to route to more than three receivers.  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Scale to arbitrary N: use one source S_A\u2013X and N sources S_Y\u1d62\u2013R\u1d62, feed the N+1 halves into an (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) near-field scatterer, and get N+1 heralding detectors\u2014yielding a one\u2192N entanglement-router node for future quantum\u2010internet topologies.  \n\u2022 Combine multiple routers to build reconfigurable network fabrics where entanglement links are formed on demand among any pair of nodes with a single joint measurement.\n\nThis multi-outcome entanglement-swap router opens a new avenue for programmable quantum networks built from a single near-field scattering device."
}

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"near field scattering\" and \"near field distribution\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. Pytheus can optimize ancilla-assisted Bell measurements via linear optics.\n    2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output. A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new capability or mechanism, not just a near-field scatterer realization of the same bidirectional teleportation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! A tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement\u2014realized by a near\u2010field scattering multiport\u2014that can be adjusted to project two photons onto the family of states {cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,\u2026}, enabling entanglement concentration on remote qubit pairs.\n    2. A programmable multi\u2010receiver router where an incoming qubit\u2019s path is scattered in the near field across N outputs in controlled superposition, performing a coherent multiplexed teleportation network.\n    3. A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010purification step: two qutrit pairs entangled with noise are fed into a near\u2010field scatterer that implements a partial\u2010swap measurement, distilling one higher\u2010fidelity qutrit pair.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration is absent from the explored list; it\u2019s a network operation (entanglement distillation), not state generation. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optics measurements.\n    2. The N\u2010receiver router edges toward controlled teleportation (already discussed) and is less focused on near\u2010field distribution\u2019s parametric role.\n    3. Qutrit purification is a natural generalization of (1) but more ambitious; better to start with qubits.\n  Step 3: Pick the tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment implements a continuously tunable Bell\u2010basis measurement via shaping a near\u2010field multiport scattering matrix\u2014and uses it to concentrate entanglement between two distant qubits.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (modes A\u2013B and C\u2013D).  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d whose internal beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases encode \u03b8.  \n    \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors for the central measurement.  \n  No cavities, no dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear\u2010optics network.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cTunable Near\u2010Field Partial\u2010Bell Measurement for Entanglement Concentration\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs:\n \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes A (0) and B (1).\n \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair between modes C (2) and D (3).\n\nPhotons B (1) and C (2) are sent into a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport\u2014that we call the \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d  The scatterer\u2019s internal beam\u2010splitter reflectivities and phase\u2010shifts are parametrized by \u03b8.  Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method).     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a quantum\u2010network transformation (not mere state generation):\n    1. A tunable near\u2010field multiport that implements a continuous family of partial\u2010Bell measurements for entanglement concentration.\n    2. A single near\u2010field scatterer that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swap orders (\u201cquantum switch\u201d).\n    3. A near\u2010field\u2010based quantum network\u2010coding router (the \u201cbutterfly network\u201d) where a central router node implements a joint measurement enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a bottleneck link.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Partial Bell concentration is known (Procrustean method) and reduces to a parameter sweep of Bell\u2010analyzer settings\u2014no new primitive.\n    2. Superposed swaps have appeared in proposals (\u201ccoherent routing of swap orders\u201d).\n    3. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurements, so this is feasible.\n  Step 3: Select idea #3.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus\u2010generated experiment realizes the quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d network coding primitive via a single near\u2010field multiport measurement at the central router\u2014simultaneously enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a shared channel.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it uses only:\n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (unknown qubits at nodes A and C),  \n    \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, C\u2013X),  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d at router X,  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding the joint measurement,  \n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear optics and post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cButterfly Quantum Network Coding via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe demonstrate the photonic version of the \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network code. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially implements a quantum switch that coherently superposes two entanglement\u2010swapping orders, using an ancilla to route which Bell measurement is applied\u2014this is functionally equivalent to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cImplementing an Entanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders.\u201d The multiport scatterer is merely an implementation variant, not a new routing primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). To be novel, you would need a genuinely new primitive beyond coherent superposition of two swap sequences, not just a different interferometer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded Photonic Fredkin Gate via Near-Field Scattering Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a probabilistic, heralded controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate on three unknown photonic qubits (control C, targets T\u2081 and T\u2082) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection, where the core interaction is a small \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport scatterer whose mode distribution is shaped by ancilla phase control.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Control photon C (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Target photon T\u2081 (mode 1)  \n   \u2013 E\u2082 \u2192 Target photon T\u2082 (mode 2)  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (Bell pairs):  \n   \u2013 S\u2083\u2084 emits ancilla photons a\u2083 (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 4)  \n   \u2013 S\u2085\u2086 emits ancilla photons a\u2085 (mode 5) & a\u2086 (mode 6)  \n\nAll seven photons are injected into a single linear-optics multiport network (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) consisting of beam-splitters and phase-shifters arranged to tightly bunch modes 0\u20266 in the near field. At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output.  \n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080][E\u2081][E\u2082]  Bell sources: [S\u2083\u2084] [S\u2085\u2086]  \n         \u2193  \n  Near-field scatterer (custom multiport)  \n         \u2193  \n near-field scattering multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cpair_sources\u201d: [[3,4],[5,6]]  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal implements a coherent superposition of teleportation channels to two receivers\u2014functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d (and closely related to \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d). The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme merely implements a continuously tunable two-photon projection (a \u201cpartial Bell measurement\u201d) in a reconfigurable multiport to concentrate entanglement from two Bell pairs. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleportation through a near\u2010field multiport is essentially the same qubit\u2010level network coding primitive already covered by the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocols (e.g. the \u201cPhotonic Qudit Butterfly\u201d for d=2 and the \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell\u2010Pair Distribution\u201d). No new routing resource or measurement capability is introduced beyond those existing schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations.
