\u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the existing heralded Fredkin primitive\u2014see \u201cHeralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. A tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement\u2014realized by a near\u2010field scattering multiport\u2014that can be adjusted to project two photons onto the family of states {cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,\u2026}, enabling entanglement concentration on remote qubit pairs.\n    2. A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010purification step: two qutrit pairs entangled with noise are fed into a near\u2010field scatterer that implements a partial\u2010swap measurement, distilling one higher\u2010fidelity qutrit pair.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). A near\u2010field\u2010based quantum network\u2010coding router (the \u201cbutterfly network\u201d) where a central router node implements a joint measurement enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a bottleneck link.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Partial Bell concentration is known (Procrustean method) and reduces to a parameter sweep of Bell\u2010analyzer settings\u2014no new primitive.\n    2. Superposed swaps have appeared in proposals (\u201ccoherent routing of swap orders\u201d).\n    3. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurements, so this is feasible.\n  Step 3: Select idea #3.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus\u2010generated experiment realizes the quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d network coding primitive via a single near\u2010field multiport measurement at the central router\u2014simultaneously enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a shared channel.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it uses only:\n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (unknown qubits at nodes A and C),  \n    \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, C\u2013X),  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d at router X,  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding the joint measurement,  \n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear optics and post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cButterfly Quantum Network Coding via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe demonstrate the photonic version of the \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network code. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations.     "output": "Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded 1\u21922 Telecloning via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement an approximate 1\u21922 telecloning network: one unknown qubit at Alice is simultaneous\u00adly teleported (cloned) to Bob and Charlie with optimal symmetric fidelity. The key is a single joint measurement at Alice realized by a small \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d (a 5\u00d75 linear\u2010optics multiport) whose internal beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases distribute the incoming modes in the near field so as to project onto the telecloning basis.\n\nSources and Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit (mode 0)  \n \u2022 EPR\u2010pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes 1 (Alice\u2019s half) & 2 (Bob)  \n \u2022 EPR\u2010pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes 3 (Alice\u2019s half) & 4 (Charlie)  \n \u2022 Optional ancilla emitter E\u2085 \u2192 mode 5 (to help realize the joint measurement)  \n\nAlice now holds modes {0,1,3,5} and sends them into a 5\u00d75 multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) built from beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters. The multiport shapes the near\u2010field mode overlap such that the four heralding detectors implement the non\u2010degenerate 1\u21922 telecloning POVM.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083 on the multiport outputs collect one photon each, signaling projection onto the telecloning basis.  \n \u2022 Bob\u2019s output is mode 2, Charlie\u2019s is mode 4\u2014they emerge in the two symmetric clones of Alice\u2019s input.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. Prepare the two Bell pairs (S\u2081,S\u2082) and the unknown input (E\u2080).  \n 2. Alice injects modes {0,1,3} (plus ancilla 5) into the near\u2010field scatterer.  \n 3. When detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083 all click once (heralding success), the remaining photons at modes 2 and 4 are left in the optimal symmetric teleclones of the input.  \n 4. No active feed-forward is needed\u2014successful heralding suffices.\n\nWhy This Is Novel:\n \u2022 No Pytheus\u2010designed experiment so far tackles 1\u21922 telecloning as a network transformation\u2014it always stops at teleportation or basic gates.  \n \u2022 Employing a single near\u2010field multiport to realize the full telecloning joint measurement (a four\u2010photon projection across input, two EPR halves, and an ancilla) is a genuinely new primitive in photonic quantum networking.\n\nFeasibility in Pytheus:\n \u2022 Uses only discrete single\u2010photon emitters (E\u2080, E\u2085) and two probabilistic EPR sources (S\u2081,S\u2082).  \n \u2022 No dynamic feedback\u2014just post\u2010selection on heralding detectors.  \n \u2022 The 5\u00d75 multiport and number\u2010resolving detectors are within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics toolbox.  \n \u2022 All physical encoding is abstract\u2014Pytheus will optimize the beam-splitter network for the telecloning measurement.\n\nSketch of Pytheus Config:\n{\n  \"description\":       \"Heralded 1\u21922 telecloning via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\":        \"teleclone_nf\",\n  \"single_emitters\":   [0,5],\n  \"pair_sources\":      [[1,2],[3,4]],\n  \"num_anc\":           4,         // detectors D0\u2026D3\n  \"in_nodes\":          [0,1,3,5], // Alice\u2019s input, her two EPR halves, plus ancilla\n  \"out_nodes\":         [2,4],     // Bob\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s outputs\n  \"removed_connections\":[          // enforce correct routing into the scatterer\n      [5,2],[5,4],[1,4],[3,2]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\":   true,\n  \"target_transformation\":\n     \"Projected heralding implements 1\u21922 symmetric telecloning\"\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 1\u2192N telecloning by adding more Bell pairs and enlarging the near-field scatterer.  \n \u2022 High-dimension telecloning (qudits) via larger multiports.  \n \u2022 Cascaded telecloning plus entanglement swapping for distributed multi-party quantum networks.\n\nThis network measurement\u2014approximate telecloning via a single near-field scatterer\u2014is a new, tunable quantum-network primitive ready for Pytheus to optimize."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"near field scattering\" and \"near field distribution\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations.     "output": "Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cReconfigurable Triangular Entanglement Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe consider three distant nodes A, B, C each holding one half of a Bell pair. The three partner halves are sent to a single central \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (linear\u2010optics multiport). By reprogramming the internal beam-splitter ratios and phase-shifts of this multiport, we can choose\u2014on demand\u2014which two of the three outer nodes will be entangled via a Bell-swap, all in one device. No matter which pair we pick (A\u2194B, B\u2194C or C\u2194A), the router implements exactly the corresponding entanglement-swapping measurement in its near-field distribution, heralding success by clicks at four ancilla detectors.\n\nSources & Modes:  \n \u2022 Pair source S_AB emits an EPR pair in modes (0\u2192A, 1\u2192X\u2081)  \n \u2022 Pair source S_BC emits an EPR pair in modes (2\u2192B, 3\u2192X\u2082)  \n \u2022 Pair source S_CA emits an EPR pair in modes (4\u2192C, 5\u2192X\u2083)  \n\nAll three ancilla halves X\u2081,X\u2082,X\u2083 (modes 1,3,5) enter a 3-input, 3-output near-field scatterer (a 3\u00d73 programmable linear-optics network). The outer halves A (0), B (2), C (4) are left untouched and constitute the final nodes.\n\nRouters & Detectors:  \n \u2022 The scatterer\u2019s three outputs feed three number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  \n \u2022 A fourth detector D\u2084 collects any leftover photon (to enforce exactly one per output).\n\nProtocol:  \n1) Before each run, the multiport is set (by classical tuning of internal phases) to one of three configurations \u201cswap AB,\u201d \u201cswap BC,\u201d or \u201cswap CA.\u201d  \n2) In \u201cswap AB\u201d mode the scatterer implements a Bell-measurement on X\u2081,X\u2082 (modes 1,3) while leaving X\u2083 spectator. A click pattern {1,1,0} at {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} heralds successful entanglement between A (0) and B (2).  \n3) In \u201cswap BC\u201d mode the same device is reconfigured to measure X\u2082,X\u2083 (modes 3,5), heralding B\u2013C entanglement upon {1,1,0}, and similarly for \u201cswap CA\u201d measuring X\u2083,X\u2081.  \n4) Thus a single near\u2010field scatterer can route entanglement between any desired pair of the three outer nodes.\n\nVisualization:  \n   Sources:   [S_AB:0\u20131]   [S_BC:2\u20133]   [S_CA:4\u20135]  \n                  \u2198   \u2198   \u2198  \n         Near-field Scatterer (3\u00d73 programmable)  \n                  \u2193   \u2193   \u2193  \n            Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083]  (+ D\u2084 for leftovers)  \n                  \u2193  \n        Outputs:   0\u2192A   2\u2192B   4\u2192C  \n\nPytheus Configuration Pointers:  \n{  \n  \"description\":      \"Reconfigurable triangular entanglement router via near-field multiport\",  \n  \"foldername\":       \"tri_router\",  \n  \"pair_sources\":     [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],    // three EPR pairs  \n  \"in_nodes\":         [1,3,5],                // ancilla halves to router  \n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,2,4],                // remaining halves at A,B,C  \n  \"num_anc\":          4,                      // D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083 + leftover D\u2084  \n  \"removed_connections\": [                     // forbid direct ancilla\u2192wrong output  \n     [1,2],[1,4],[3,0],[3,4],[5,0],[5,2]  \n  ],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"program_modes\": [                            // three target measurement bases  \n    { \"swap\": \"AB\", \"measure_modes\": [1,3] },  \n    { \"swap\": \"BC\", \"measure_modes\": [3,5] },  \n    { \"swap\": \"CA\", \"measure_modes\": [5,1] }  \n  ]  \n}  \n\nGeneralizations:  \n\u2013 With N outer nodes and N EPR-halves, one can build an N-port programmable entanglement router that selects any link by reprogramming a single near-field scatterer.  \n\u2013 By preparing an ancilla photon in superposition of the three \u201cmodes,\u201d one could even realize coherent superpositions of which swap is performed, opening the door to quantum\u2010control of network topology.  \n\u2013 The same device can be cascaded in quantum repeater chains: intermediate modules route entanglement on demand across large networks.\n\nWhy this is novel:  \nNo existing Pytheus\u2010designed experiment realizes a single multiport that, by simple near-field reprogramming, can entangle any chosen pair among three (or more) remote nodes. This is a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014an on-demand entanglement router.\n\nWhy this is feasible:  \nIt uses only three probabilistic photon-pair sources, one small linear-optical multiport, and number-resolving detectors\u2014precisely the toolbox Pytheus can optimize. There is no forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback control, only post-selected Bell-swap measurements reconfigured via static phase settings."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that uses a multi-port near-field-like interferometer to coherently route entanglement between different distant pairs, creating a superposition of network topologies (i.e. a superposition of two different entanglement-swapping orders).\n    2. A parallel teleportation network in which two qubits are teleported simultaneously through a single near-field multi-mode \u201cbeam splitter\u201d device that implements two Bell measurements at once by scattering modes in the near field.\n    3. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. It is not pure state generation\u2014it\u2019s a process that yields a superposition of two different swap topologies. Pytheus can optimize ancilla-assisted Bell measurements via linear optics.\n    2. The parallel-teleportation idea is a direct extension of standard teleportation and uses only two simultaneous Bell measurements; it\u2019s certainly doable but less novel than a superposed routing.\n    3. A full d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding open problem; linear-optics schemes typically only get partial success. It might be too ambitious\u2014Pytheus may struggle to find a complete discrimination network without exotic interactions.\n  Step 3: Pick the most promising: the \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement routing.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement-swapping orders (i.e. two network topologies) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection. No existing Pytheus design explores a superposition of different swap operations.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires: two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon ancilla emitter to control the effective near-field-like multi-port coupler, linear-optics elements (beam splitters, phase shifters) to build the central multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer,\u201d and number-resolving detectors. No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we are targeting an entanglement-swapping process, not raw state generation.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). To be novel, you would need a genuinely new primitive beyond coherent superposition of two swap sequences, not just a different interferometer.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cnear-field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear-field distribution\u201d into a quantum-network primitive (not mere state generation):\n 1. A heralded linear-optical Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate realized by a near-field multiport \u201cscatterer,\u201d where the near-field distribution of modes (phase pattern) is controlled by the ancilla\u2019s path, effecting a conditional swap via teleportation\u2010inspired Bell measurements.\n 2. A \u201cbroadcast\u2010in\u2010superposition\u201d entanglement router: one sender and N receivers are connected via a near-field multiport coupler that coherently routes an entanglement link to one of the N receivers in superposition, exploiting near-field scattering to implement a programmable quantum switch network.\n 3. A full d-dimensional Bell-basis analyzer (for qudits) using a near-field scattering multiport that shapes the near-field distribution so that each of the d\u00b2 Bell states maps onto a unique click pattern\u2014serving as an unambiguous high-dimensional Bell measurement device.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n 1. The Fredkin\u2010gate idea is not on the explored list (they have CNOT and Toffoli, but no Fredkin). It\u2019s a gate (a network transformation), not static state generation. Pytheus can optimize ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optics networks for Bell measurements and multi-photon interference.\n 2. The broadcast-in-superposition router is conceptually novel but loosely specified; it edges close to state generation (GHZ-type) or coherent swap, and may be too speculative for Pytheus.\n 3. A complete d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding challenge; pure linear-optics unambiguous discrimination for all d\u00b2 states is likely beyond Pytheus\u2019s reach without nonlinearities.\nStep 3: Pick the most promising: the heralded Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate via near-field scattering.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design implements the full controlled-SWAP gate\u2014only CNOT and Toffoli have been demonstrated. Embedding the SWAP control in a near-field multiport \u201cscatterer\u201d that uses ancilla\u2010controlled phase patterns to route and swap two unknown photonic qubits is a fresh quantum-network primitive.\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it only uses: \n  \u2022 Three single-photon emitters (control + two targets)  \n  \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (four ancilla photons)  \n  \u2022 A linear-optics multiport acting as a near-field scatterer  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors for heralding  \nNo cavities, no hyper-entanglement, no dynamic feedback. We are targeting a gate (network transformation), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded Photonic Fredkin Gate via Near-Field Scattering Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a probabilistic, heralded controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate on three unknown photonic qubits (control C, targets T\u2081 and T\u2082) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection, where the core interaction is a small \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport scatterer whose mode distribution is shaped by ancilla phase control.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Control photon C (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Target photon T\u2081 (mode 1)  \n   \u2013 E\u2082 \u2192 Target photon T\u2082 (mode 2)  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (Bell pairs):  \n   \u2013 S\u2083\u2084 emits ancilla photons a\u2083 (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 4)  \n   \u2013 S\u2085\u2086 emits ancilla photons a\u2085 (mode 5) & a\u2086 (mode 6)  \n\nAll seven photons are injected into a single linear-optics multiport network (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) consisting of beam-splitters and phase-shifters arranged to tightly bunch modes 0\u20266 in the near field. At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output. \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a quantum-network primitive (avoiding pure state generation):\n    1. A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network primitive (not mere state generation):\n    1. A tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement\u2014realized by a near\u2010field scattering multiport\u2014that can be adjusted to project two photons onto the family of states {cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,\u2026}, enabling entanglement concentration on remote qubit pairs.\n    2. A programmable multi\u2010receiver router where an incoming qubit\u2019s path is scattered in the near field across N outputs in controlled superposition, performing a coherent multiplexed teleportation network.\n    3. A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010purification step: two qutrit pairs entangled with noise are fed into a near\u2010field scatterer that implements a partial\u2010swap measurement, distilling one higher\u2010fidelity qutrit pair.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration is absent from the explored list; it\u2019s a network operation (entanglement distillation), not state generation. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optics measurements.\n    2. The N\u2010receiver router edges toward controlled teleportation (already discussed) and is less focused on near\u2010field distribution\u2019s parametric role.\n    3. Qutrit purification is a natural generalization of (1) but more ambitious; better to start with qubits.\n  Step 3: Pick the tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment implements a continuously tunable Bell\u2010basis measurement via shaping a near\u2010field multiport scattering matrix\u2014and uses it to concentrate entanglement between two distant qubits.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (modes A\u2013B and C\u2013D).  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d whose internal beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases encode \u03b8.  \n    \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors for the central measurement.  \n  No cavities, no dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear\u2010optics network.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cTunable Near\u2010Field Partial\u2010Bell Measurement for Entanglement Concentration\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs:\n \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes A (0) and B (1).\n \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair between modes C (2) and D (3).\n\nPhotons B (1) and C (2) are sent into a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport\u2014that we call the \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d  The scatterer\u2019s internal beam\u2010splitter reflectivities and phase\u2010shifts are parametrized by \u03b8.  Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). A single near\u2010field scatterer that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swap orders (\u201cquantum switch\u201d).\n    3. A near\u2010field\u2010based quantum network\u2010coding router (the \u201cbutterfly network\u201d) where a central router node implements a joint measurement enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a bottleneck link.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network primitive without pure state generation:\n    1. A single near\u2010field multiport that simultaneously performs entanglement purification (parity check) and subsequent entanglement swapping on two incoming noisy Bell pairs, compressing the two\u2010step repeater operation into one device.\n    2. A programmable multi\u2010receiver near\u2010field router that splits a single incoming qubit among N receivers via controlled\u2010partial teleportation channels\u2014effectively a \u201cquantum multicasting\u201d primitive.\n    3. A near\u2010field multichannel Bell\u2010measurement device that reconfigures (via an ancilla) between d\u2010dimensional Bell analyzers on demand\u2014serving as a universal high\u2010dimensional teleportation hub.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Combined purification\u2009+\u2009swapping in one near\u2010field scatterer is neither in the explored list nor discussed above. It is a genuine network transformation (repeater primitive), not mere state creation. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurements to realize parity checks and Bell projections in one shot.\n    2. Quantum multicasting edges toward state\u2010generation (GHZ) or broadcast\u2014too similar to superposed teleportation routers already considered.\n    3. Reconfigurable high\u2010D Bell analyzer is likely out of reach for pure linear\u2010optics unambiguous discrimination in all d\u00b2 cases.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 1.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment fuses entanglement purification and entanglement swapping into a single near\u2010field scattering network. It realizes the core repeater building block in one ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurement, shrinking latency and resource overhead.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n     \u2022 two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (noisy EPR links),  \n     \u2022 one additional ancilla Bell pair,  \n     \u2022 a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer,\u201d  \n     \u2022 number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n  No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we target a network transformation (purification+swap), not raw state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cIntegrated Entanglement Purification and Swapping via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nIn a quantum repeater at node X we compress the two critical operations\u2014entanglement purification (parity check) followed by entanglement swapping\u2014into one ancilla\u2010assisted near\u2010field multiport measurement. Two noisy Bell\u2010pairs (S\u2081 between A\u2013X, S\u2082 between X\u2013B) arrive at X on modes 1 and 2 (the \u201csignal halves\u201d). An ancilla Bell\u2010pair S\u2083 on modes 3\u20134 provides the resource photons for both the parity check and the subsequent Bell projection. All four photons (modes 1,2,3,4) enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d). The near\u2010field distribution of internal interference patterns (beam\u2010splitters & phase shifts) is optimized so that:\n\n  Step A (Parity Check): Conditioned on a specific two\u2010click pattern in detectors D\u2085 and D\u2086, the parity of modes 1 and 2 is measured, projecting them onto the even\u2010parity subspace and thus purifying the remaining halves at A and B.  \n  Step B (Swap): Simultaneously, the same interferometric network routes the purified qubit halves through an effective Bell\u2010measurement (on the purified ancilla halves) and heralds a successful entanglement swap between A and B via detectors D\u2087 and D\u2088.\n\nWhen all four heralding detectors (D\u2085\u2026D\u2088) click once each, node X has effectively performed purification\u2009+\u2009swapping in one shot, delivering a higher\u2010fidelity entangled link between A and B (modes 0 and 5).\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0:A, 1:X\u2081]  \n \u2022 Pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2:X\u2082, 3:B]  \n \u2022 Ancilla pair   S\u2083 \u2192 modes [4:X\u2083, 5:X\u2084]  \n\nAll four X\u2010modes [1,2,4,5] are fed into the 4\u00d74 near\u2010field scatterer. Outputs:\n \u2022 Logical outputs: mode 0 (A) unchanged, mode 3 (B) unchanged.  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors: D\u2085\u2026D\u2088 on the four scatterer outputs.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Integrated entanglement purification + swap via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"purify_swap_scatter\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [4,0],[4,3],[5,0],[5,3]  // ancilla halves only go into scatterer\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement\": [\n    \"parity_check(1,2) \u2192 detectors D5,D6\",\n    \"bell_proj(remaining_modes) \u2192 detectors D7,D8\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to three or more pairs: fuse multi\u2010round purification + multi\u2010node swapping in one multiport.  \n\u2022 Replace the ancilla Bell\u2010pair with multiple ancilla pairs for higher\u2010order distillation.  \n\u2022 Adapt to d\u2010dimensional qudits by increasing the scatterer size\u2014yielding one\u2010shot purification/swapping for cluster\u2010state repeaters.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrating purification and swapping in a single near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is a new repeater primitive tailor\u2010made for Pytheus\u2019s ancilla\u2010assisted multiport design capabilities."
