    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially implements a quantum switch that coherently superposes two entanglement\u2010swapping orders, using an ancilla to route which Bell measurement is applied\u2014this is functionally equivalent to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cImplementing an Entanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders.\u201d The multiport scatterer is merely an implementation variant, not a new routing primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). To be novel, you would need a genuinely new primitive beyond coherent superposition of two swap sequences, not just a different interferometer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded Photonic Fredkin Gate via Near-Field Scattering Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a probabilistic, heralded controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate on three unknown photonic qubits (control C, targets T\u2081 and T\u2082) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection, where the core interaction is a small \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport scatterer whose mode distribution is shaped by ancilla phase control.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Control photon C (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Target photon T\u2081 (mode 1)  \n   \u2013 E\u2082 \u2192 Target photon T\u2082 (mode 2)  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (Bell pairs):  \n   \u2013 S\u2083\u2084 emits ancilla photons a\u2083 (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 4)  \n   \u2013 S\u2085\u2086 emits ancilla photons a\u2085 (mode 5) & a\u2086 (mode 6)  \n\nAll seven photons are injected into a single linear-optics multiport network (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) consisting of beam-splitters and phase-shifters arranged to tightly bunch modes 0\u20266 in the near field. At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output.  \n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080][E\u2081][E\u2082]  Bell sources: [S\u2083\u2084] [S\u2085\u2086]  \n         \u2193  \n  Near-field scatterer (custom multiport)  \n         \u2193  \n  Outputs: [D\u2080:C\u2032][D\u2081:T\u2081\u2032][D\u2082:T\u2082\u2032][D\u2083][D\u2084][D\u2085][D\u2086]  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cHeralded Fredkin gate via near-field scattering multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cpair_sources\u201d: [[3,4],[5,6]]  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new mechanism or capability beyond re-implementing the same controlled-SWAP.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal implements a coherent superposition of teleportation channels to two receivers\u2014functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d (and closely related to \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d). Swapping out a different multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) without a new routing primitive or resource advantage does not add genuine novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new mechanism or capability beyond re\u2010implementing controlled, dual\u2010destination teleportation with a different interferometer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSimultaneous Bidirectional Teleportation via Near-Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe teleport two unknown photonic qubits A and B to each other in one device. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The bidirectional teleportation scheme is functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits,\u201d merely swapped in a different interferometer geometry. Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme merely implements a continuously tunable two-photon projection (a \u201cpartial Bell measurement\u201d) in a reconfigurable multiport to concentrate entanglement from two Bell pairs. Entanglement concentration via rotated Bell\u2010basis measurements is a textbook protocol, and any 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network can be programmed to project onto an arbitrary two\u2010qubit basis. This offers no new network primitive or resource trade-off beyond standard entanglement swapping/distillation, so it lacks the genuine novelty required for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). Replacing the basis angle \u03b8 with a \u201cnear-field multiport\u201d control does not introduce a new primitive\u2014any universal multiport could already realize this continuous family. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new measurement resource or an unexpected performance advantage (e.g. loss-tolerance, non-Hermitian enhancement, topological protection) not reducible to a mere parameter sweep of a Bell analyzer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cButterfly Quantum Network Coding via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe demonstrate the photonic version of the \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network code. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleportation through a near\u2010field multiport is essentially the same qubit\u2010level network coding primitive already covered by the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocols (e.g. the \u201cPhotonic Qudit Butterfly\u201d for d=2 and the \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell\u2010Pair Distribution\u201d). To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new primitive\u2014e.g. a different nonlocal measurement that cannot be reduced to the previous butterfly joint\u2010swap, or an unexpected performance advantage (loss tolerance, topological protection, higher success scaling) beyond simply re\u2010expressing the standard cross\u2010teleportation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cIntegrated Entanglement Purification and Swapping via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nIn a quantum repeater at node X we compress the two critical operations\u2014entanglement purification (parity check) followed by entanglement swapping\u2014into one ancilla\u2010assisted near\u2010field multiport measurement. Two noisy Bell\u2010pairs (S\u2081 between A\u2013X, S\u2082 between X\u2013B) arrive at X on modes 1 and 2 (the \u201csignal halves\u201d). An ancilla Bell\u2010pair S\u2083 on modes 3\u20134 provides the resource photons for both the parity check and the subsequent Bell projection. All four photons (modes 1,2,3,4) enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d). The near\u2010field distribution of internal interference patterns (beam\u2010splitters & phase shifts) is optimized so that:\n\n  Step A (Parity Check): Conditioned on a specific two\u2010click pattern in detectors D\u2085 and D\u2086, the parity of modes 1 and 2 is measured, projecting them onto the even\u2010parity subspace and thus purifying the remaining halves at A and B.  \n  Step B (Swap): Simultaneously, the same interferometric network routes the purified qubit halves through an effective Bell\u2010measurement (on the purified ancilla halves) and heralds a successful entanglement swap between A and B via detectors D\u2087 and D\u2088.\n\nWhen all four heralding detectors (D\u2085\u2026D\u2088) click once each, node X has effectively performed purification\u2009+\u2009swapping in one shot, delivering a higher\u2010fidelity entangled link between A and B (modes 0 and 5).\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0:A, 1:X\u2081]  \n \u2022 Pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2:X\u2082, 3:B]  \n \u2022 Ancilla pair   S\u2083 \u2192 modes [4:X\u2083, 5:X\u2084]  \n\nAll four X\u2010modes [1,2,4,5] are fed into the 4\u00d74 near\u2010field scatterer. Outputs:\n \u2022 Logical outputs: mode 0 (A) unchanged, mode 3 (B) unchanged.  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors: D\u2085\u2026D\u2088 on the four scatterer outputs.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Integrated entanglement purification + swap via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"purify_swap_scatter\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [4,0],[4,3],[5,0],[5,3]  // ancilla halves only go into scatterer\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement\": [\n    \"parity_check(1,2) \u2192 detectors D5,D6\",\n    \"bell_proj(remaining_modes) \u2192 detectors D7,D8\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to three or more pairs: fuse multi\u2010round purification + multi\u2010node swapping in one multiport.  \n\u2022 Replace the ancilla Bell\u2010pair with multiple ancilla pairs for higher\u2010order distillation.  \n\u2022 Adapt to d\u2010dimensional qudits by increasing the scatterer size\u2014yielding one\u2010shot purification/swapping for cluster\u2010state repeaters.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrating purification and swapping in a single near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is a new repeater primitive tailor\u2010made for Pytheus\u2019s ancilla\u2010assisted multiport design capabilities.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This integrated purification-and-swap node is effectively the same \u201cone-shot repeater\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (e.g. the \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater\u201d which mixes the inner modes of two imperfect links into a single high-fidelity Bell pair). Folding parity checking and swapping into one multiport adds only an implementation tweak, not a new network transformation or resource advantage.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the existing single-shot purification+swap repeater primitive. To be novel, you\u2019d need a fundamentally new measurement capability or performance feature (e.g. genuine higher-order distillation without additional ancillas, loss-tolerance beyond post-selection, or a non-Hermitian/ topologically protected enhancement) rather than just merging two textbook steps into one multiport."

A parallel teleportation network in which two qubits are teleported simultaneously through a single near-field multi-mode \u201cbeam splitter\u201d device that implements two Bell measurements at once by scattering modes in the near field.\n    3. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. A full d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding open problem; linear-optics schemes typically only get partial success. No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we are targeting an entanglement-swapping process, not raw state generation.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. A tunable near\u2010field multiport that implements a continuous family of partial\u2010Bell measurements for entanglement concentration.\n    2. A single near\u2010field scatterer that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swap orders (\u201cquantum switch\u201d).\n    3. A near\u2010field\u2010based quantum network\u2010coding router (the \u201cbutterfly network\u201d) where a central router node implements a joint measurement enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a bottleneck link.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Partial Bell concentration is known (Procrustean method) and reduces to a parameter sweep of Bell\u2010analyzer settings\u2014no new primitive.\n    2. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations. Two noisy Bell\u2010pairs (S\u2081 between A\u2013X, S\u2082 between X\u2013B) arrive at X on modes 1 and 2 (the \u201csignal halves\u201d). An ancilla Bell\u2010pair S\u2083 on modes 3\u20134 provides the resource photons for both the parity check and the subsequent Bell projection. All four photons (modes 1,2,3,4) enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d). The near\u2010field distribution of internal interference patterns (beam\u2010splitters & phase shifts) is optimized so that:\n\n  Step A (Parity Check): Conditioned on a specific two\u2010click pattern in detectors D\u2085 and D\u2086, the parity of modes 1 and 2 is measured, projecting them onto the even\u2010parity subspace and thus purifying the remaining halves at A and B.  \n  Step B (Swap): Simultaneously, the same interferometric network routes the purified qubit halves through an effective Bell\u2010measurement (on the purified ancilla halves) and heralds a successful entanglement swap between A and B via detectors D\u2087 and D\u2088.\n\nWhen all four heralding detectors (D\u2085\u2026D\u2088) click once each, node X has effectively performed purification\u2009+\u2009swapping in one shot, delivering a higher\u2010fidelity entangled link between A and B (modes 0 and 5).\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0:A, 1:X\u2081]  \n \u2022 Pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2:X\u2082, 3:B]  \n \u2022 Ancilla pair   S\u2083 \u2192 modes [4:X\u2083, 5:X\u2084]  \n\nAll four X\u2010modes [1,2,4,5] are fed into the 4\u00d74 near\u2010field scatterer. Outputs:\n \u2022 Logical outputs: mode 0 (A) unchanged, mode 3 (B) unchanged.  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors: D\u2085\u2026D\u2088 on the four scatterer outputs.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Integrated entanglement purification + swap via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"purify_swap_scatter\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [4,0],[4,3],[5,0],[5,3]  // ancilla halves only go into scatterer\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement\": [\n    \"parity_check(1,2) \u2192 detectors D5,D6\",\n    \"bell_proj(remaining_modes) \u2192 detectors D7,D8\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to three or more pairs: fuse multi\u2010round purification + multi\u2010node swapping in one multiport.  \n\u2022 Replace the ancilla Bell\u2010pair with multiple ancilla pairs for higher\u2010order distillation.  \n\u2022 Adapt to d\u2010dimensional qudits by increasing the scatterer size\u2014yielding one\u2010shot purification/swapping for cluster\u2010state repeaters.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrating purification and swapping in a single near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is a new repeater primitive tailor\u2010made for Pytheus\u2019s ancilla\u2010assisted multiport design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the existing single-shot purification+swap repeater primitive. This analyzer is the key network measurement for conference\u2010key distribution, three-party teleportation, and secret sharing.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Unknown qubits (Alice, Bob, Charlie) are single photons from emitters E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 in modes 0,1,2.  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources supply ancilla photons on modes [3,4] and [5,6].  \n \u2022 All seven photons enter a programmable 7\u00d77 \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a dense linear-optics multiport whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phases create a rich near-field mode distribution).\n \u2022 Outputs feed seven number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer is optimized so that each of the eight GHZ input states uniquely triggers one of eight predetermined four-click patterns among {D\u2080\u2026D\u2086}.  \n \u2022 Condition on the correct four-click signature \u2192 we herald which GHZ basis vector was present.  \n \u2022 This measurement is non-destructive on the three input qubits (they\u2019re measured), and its only resource is linear optics + ancilla + postselection\u2014no cavities, no active feed-forward.\n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080\u21920][E\u2081\u21921][E\u2082\u21922]  Bell-sources: [S\u2083\u2084\u21923,4][S\u2085\u2086\u21925,6]  \n           \u2193  \n     Near-Field Scatterer (7\u00d77 multiport)  \n           \u2193  \n     Detectors: [D\u2080][D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084][D\u2085][D\u2086]  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"GHZ-basis analyzer via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"ghz_analyzer_nf\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[3,4],[5,6]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,2,3,5],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [],               // measurement device\n  \"removed_connections\": [            // ancilla cannot bypass the scatterer\n    [3,0],[3,1],[3,2],[5,0],[5,1],[5,2]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"000+111\",\"000\u2212111\",\"001+110\",\"001\u2212110\",\n    \"010+101\",\"010\u2212101\",\"011+100\",\"011\u2212100\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to d-qudit GHZ analyzers by scaling the near-field scatterer to d\u00b3 modes and using higher-dimensional Bell pairs.  \n \u2022 Embed this analyzer as the measurement node in multi-party teleportation and secret-sharing networks.  \n \u2022 Cascade multiple analyzers for network coding in complex multiparty topologies.\n\nThis is a genuinely new network measurement primitive\u2014heralded, linear-optics, ancilla-assisted, and leveraging a near-field scattering multiport\u2014ideal for Pytheus to optimize and for writing a high-impact theory+experiment proposal."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially implements a quantum switch that coherently superposes two entanglement\u2010swapping orders, using an ancilla to route which Bell measurement is applied\u2014this is functionally equivalent to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cImplementing an Entanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders.\u201d The multiport scatterer is merely an implementation variant, not a new routing primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output. The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal implements a coherent superposition of teleportation channels to two receivers\u2014functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d (and closely related to \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d). Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The bidirectional teleportation scheme is functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits,\u201d merely swapped in a different interferometer geometry.
