A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. A tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement\u2014realized by a near\u2010field scattering multiport\u2014that can be adjusted to project two photons onto the family of states {cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,\u2026}, enabling entanglement concentration on remote qubit pairs.\n    2. A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010purification step: two qutrit pairs entangled with noise are fed into a near\u2010field scatterer that implements a partial\u2010swap measurement, distilling one higher\u2010fidelity qutrit pair.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to weave \u201cnear\u2010field scattering\u201d and \u201cnear\u2010field distribution\u201d into a quantum\u2010network transformation (not mere state generation):\n    1. A tunable near\u2010field multiport that implements a continuous family of partial\u2010Bell measurements for entanglement concentration.\n    2. A single near\u2010field scatterer that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement\u2010swap orders (\u201cquantum switch\u201d).\n    3. A near\u2010field\u2010based quantum network\u2010coding router (the \u201cbutterfly network\u201d) where a central router node implements a joint measurement enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a bottleneck link.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Superposed swaps have appeared in proposals (\u201ccoherent routing of swap orders\u201d).\n    3. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurements, so this is feasible.\n  Step 3: Select idea #3.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus\u2010generated experiment realizes the quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d network coding primitive via a single near\u2010field multiport measurement at the central router\u2014simultaneously enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a shared channel.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it uses only:\n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (unknown qubits at nodes A and C),  \n    \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, C\u2013X),  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d at router X,  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding the joint measurement,  \n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear optics and post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cButterfly Quantum Network Coding via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe demonstrate the photonic version of the \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network code. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations. An unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 lives in a single-photon emitter E\u2080 (mode 0). Two blank ancilla qubits (|0\u27e9) are supplied by probabilistic pair sources S\u2081 (modes 1\u20132) and S\u2082 (modes 3\u20134). All five photons enter a single 5\u00d75 \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport (a dense beam-splitter/phase-shifter network whose near-field intensity distribution is optimized). At the outputs:\n\n\u2022 Modes 0\u2032 and 1\u2032 carry two approximate clones of |\u03c8\u27e9 with optimal fidelity 5/6.  \n\u2022 The remaining three output modes are sent to heralding detectors D\u2082,D\u2083,D\u2084.  \n\u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2082,D\u2083,D\u2084}={1,1,1} (one photon each), we post-select the events in which the first two output modes indeed contain the two clones.\n\nThis device realizes the transformation  \n\u2003|\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2009\u2297\u2009|00\u27e9\u2081\u2082\u2009\u2297\u2009|00\u27e9\u2083\u2084  \n\u2192\u2095  \n\u2003|\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2032\u2009\u2297\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9\u2081\u2032\u2009\u2297\u2009|garbage\u27e9\u2082\u2032 plus herald clicks  \nwith the universal-cloner fidelity F=5/6, all in one compact multiport.\n\nVisualization:  \nEmitters & Pair Sources:  \n [E\u2080\u21920]\u2003[S\u2081\u21921,2]\u2003[S\u2082\u21923,4]  \n      \u2193  \n5\u00d75 Near-Field Scatterer  \n      \u2193  \n Outputs: [0\u2032: clone\u2081] [1\u2032: clone\u2082]  \n Heralding Detectors: [D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded 1\u21922 universal cloner via near-field scatterer\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"ucloner_nf\",  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0],  \n  \"pair_sources\":    [[1,2],[3,4]],  \n  \"num_anc\":          3,       # three heralding detectors  \n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,3],  \n  \"out_nodes\":      [0,1],     # modes carrying the two clones  \n  \"removed_connections\": [      # ancilla halves go only to herald detectors  \n    [2,0],[2,1],[4,0],[4,1]  \n  ],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"target_transformation\": {    # abstract mapping for basis states  \n     \"00000->00\": 5/6,  \n     \"10000->10\": 5/6  \n  }  \n}\n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2022 By adding more ancilla pairs and an N\u00d7N near-field scatterer one can realize 1\u2192N universal cloners for qubits (or qudits), opening a family of programmable cloning devices.  \n\u2022 Such a device is a true network primitive\u2014an operation on an unknown qubit in to two separate nodes\u2014rather than mere state generation.  \n\u2022 A compact proof-of-principle would pave the way to multiplexed quantum\u2010network transforms (e.g. approximate cloning, fan-out, quantum broadcast) all realized by tuning the same near-field multiport."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"near field scattering\" and \"near field distribution\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that uses a multi-port near-field-like interferometer to coherently route entanglement between different distant pairs, creating a superposition of network topologies (i.e. a superposition of two different entanglement-swapping orders).\n    2. A parallel teleportation network in which two qubits are teleported simultaneously through a single near-field multi-mode \u201cbeam splitter\u201d device that implements two Bell measurements at once by scattering modes in the near field.\n    3. A high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer realized by a near-field scattering multiport that unambiguously discriminates all d\u00b2 Bell states (e.g. qutrits), by mapping each Bell basis vector onto a unique detector click pattern.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. \u201cQuantum switch\u201d of entanglement routing is not in the existing list. It is not pure state generation\u2014it\u2019s a process that yields a superposition of two different swap topologies. Pytheus can optimize ancilla-assisted Bell measurements via linear optics.\n    2. The parallel-teleportation idea is a direct extension of standard teleportation and uses only two simultaneous Bell measurements; it\u2019s certainly doable but less novel than a superposed routing.\n    3. A full d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding open problem; linear-optics schemes typically only get partial success. It might be too ambitious\u2014Pytheus may struggle to find a complete discrimination network without exotic interactions.\n  Step 3: Pick the most promising: the \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement routing.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement-swapping orders (i.e. two network topologies) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection. No existing Pytheus design explores a superposition of different swap operations.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires: two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon ancilla emitter to control the effective near-field-like multi-port coupler, linear-optics elements (beam splitters, phase shifters) to build the central multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer,\u201d and number-resolving detectors. No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we are targeting an entanglement-swapping process, not raw state generation.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Routing via Near\u2010Field Multiport Scattering\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits a Bell pair between modes A and B.\n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits a Bell pair between modes C and D.\nWe also have a single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. All six photons enter a programmable linear\u2010optical multiport network that mimics a \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d The network implements two possible Bell\u2010measurements on (B,D) or on (A,C), controlled coherently by the ancilla photon\u2019s path. After interference, we detect:\n  \u2013 Four detectors D\u2081..D\u2084 at the outputs of the multiport (heralding successful swap),\n  \u2013 Two output modes at A\u2032 and C\u2032 which become entangled with B\u2032 and D\u2032 in two different ways.\n\nGoal:\nConditioned on one click pattern among D\u2081..D\u2084 and the ancilla\u2019s outcome, we post\u2010select a three\u2010photon projection that yields the superposition\n  (|Swap-order-1\u27e9 + |Swap-order-2\u27e9)/\u221a2,\nwhere\n  \u2022 Swap-order-1 entangles A with D\u2032 and C with B\u2032 (first\u2010order swapping),\n  \u2022 Swap-order-2 entangles A with C\u2032 and B with D\u2032 (second\u2010order swapping).\nThus the final state is a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement\u2010routing topologies\u2014a genuine \u201cquantum switch.\u201d\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources: [S\u2081: A\u2013B], [S\u2082: C\u2013D], [E: ancilla]\n  \u2193\n  Multiport \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (programmable beam splitters & phases)\n  \u2193\n  Detectors: [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  // heralding outputs\n  Outputs: A\u2032 and B\u2032 and C\u2032 and D\u2032                 \n\nKey Pytheus config pointers:\n  \u2022 num_pre = 1 (one pre\u2010entangled pair each at S\u2081,S\u2082)\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [E] (ancilla path superposition)\n  \u2022 num_anc = 0 (no extra ancilla photons beyond E; ancilla is emitter)\n  \u2022 removed_connections: enforce that no Bell\u2010pair source sends photons directly to unintended detectors (e.g., A\u2192D\u2081..D\u2084).\n  \u2022 target_quantum: abstract superposition of two distinct 4-photon post-selected swap outcomes, which Pytheus will optimize the multiport to realize.\n  \u2022 number_resolving = True.\n\nGeneralization:\nBy increasing the number of input Bell pairs and ancilla photons prepared in higher\u2010dimensional superposition states, one can build larger \u201cquantum switch\u201d networks that coherently superpose more than two entanglement\u2010routing patterns\u2014opening a new avenue for superposed network topologies and programmable quantum internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d proposal (Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders). A heralded linear-optical Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate realized by a near-field multiport \u201cscatterer,\u201d where the near-field distribution of modes (phase pattern) is controlled by the ancilla\u2019s path, effecting a conditional swap via teleportation\u2010inspired Bell measurements.\n 2. A \u201cbroadcast\u2010in\u2010superposition\u201d entanglement router: one sender and N receivers are connected via a near-field multiport coupler that coherently routes an entanglement link to one of the N receivers in superposition, exploiting near-field scattering to implement a programmable quantum switch network.\n 3. A full d-dimensional Bell-basis analyzer (for qudits) using a near-field scattering multiport that shapes the near-field distribution so that each of the d\u00b2 Bell states maps onto a unique click pattern\u2014serving as an unambiguous high-dimensional Bell measurement device.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n 1. Pytheus can optimize ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optics networks for Bell measurements and multi-photon interference.\n 2. The broadcast-in-superposition router is conceptually novel but loosely specified; it edges close to state generation (GHZ-type) or coherent swap, and may be too speculative for Pytheus.\n 3. A complete d-dimensional Bell analyzer is a longstanding challenge; pure linear-optics unambiguous discrimination for all d\u00b2 states is likely beyond Pytheus\u2019s reach without nonlinearities.\nStep 3: Pick the most promising: the heralded Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate via near-field scattering.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design implements the full controlled-SWAP gate\u2014only CNOT and Toffoli have been demonstrated. Embedding the SWAP control in a near-field multiport \u201cscatterer\u201d that uses ancilla\u2010controlled phase patterns to route and swap two unknown photonic qubits is a fresh quantum-network primitive.\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it only uses: \n  \u2022 Three single-photon emitters (control + two targets)  \n  \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (four ancilla photons)  \n  \u2022 A linear-optics multiport acting as a near-field scatterer  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors for heralding  \nNo cavities, no hyper-entanglement, no dynamic feedback. We are targeting a gate (network transformation), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cHeralded Photonic Fredkin Gate via Near-Field Scattering Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a probabilistic, heralded controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate on three unknown photonic qubits (control C, targets T\u2081 and T\u2082) using only linear optics, ancilla photons, and post-selection, where the core interaction is a small \u201cnear-field\u201d multiport scatterer whose mode distribution is shaped by ancilla phase control.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Control photon C (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Target photon T\u2081 (mode 1)  \n   \u2013 E\u2082 \u2192 Target photon T\u2082 (mode 2)  \n \u2022 Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (Bell pairs):  \n   \u2013 S\u2083\u2084 emits ancilla photons a\u2083 (mode 3) & a\u2084 (mode 4)  \n   \u2013 S\u2085\u2086 emits ancilla photons a\u2085 (mode 5) & a\u2086 (mode 6)  \n\nAll seven photons are injected into a single linear-optics multiport network (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) consisting of beam-splitters and phase-shifters arranged to tightly bunch modes 0\u20266 in the near field. At the outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 collect the outgoing modes of C\u2032, T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032 (the three logical outputs).  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 are four number-resolving heralding detectors for a\u2083\u2026a\u2086.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 Upon the click pattern {D\u2083,D\u2084,D\u2085,D\u2086} = {1,1,1,1} (one photon each), post-select the remaining photons at D\u2080,D\u2081,D\u2082.  \n \u2022 The design of the multiport ensures that\u2014in this heralded event\u2014the joint mapping on (C,T\u2081,T\u2082) implements the controlled-SWAP:\n   \u2013 If control C=|0\u27e9, targets exit unchanged at T\u2081\u2032, T\u2082\u2032.  \n   \u2013 If control C=|1\u27e9, the two target qubits swap places at the output.  \n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [E\u2080][E\u2081][E\u2082]  Bell sources: [S\u2083\u2084] [S\u2085\u2086]  \n         \u2193  \n  Near-field scatterer (custom multiport)  \n         \u2193  \n  Outputs: [D\u2080:C\u2032][D\u2081:T\u2081\u2032][D\u2082:T\u2082\u2032][D\u2083][D\u2084][D\u2085][D\u2086]  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cHeralded Fredkin gate via near-field scattering multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cpair_sources\u201d: [[3,4],[5,6]]  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2]  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: enforce no direct source\u2192output for ancilla pairs  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d: Controlled-SWAP truth table (implicitly through input\u2013output mapping)  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy extending to d-level photonic qudits (replacing each emitter with a d-mode source, ancilla Bell pairs of dimension d), one can design higher-dimensional Fredkin gates or multi-target conditional permutations, all via programmable near-field scattering couplers.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the existing heralded Fredkin primitive\u2014see \u201cHeralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target A heralded Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate built as a near-field multiport scatterer whose local phase pattern steers the swap operation.\n    2. A \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct entanglement-swap orders by tuning a near-field multiport\u2019s scattering distribution with an ancilla.\n    3. A teleportation-router that uses a near-field multiport to perform two alternative Bell-measurements on one unknown qubit and two EPR halves, thereby teleporting the state to one of two receivers\u2014potentially in superposition if an ancilla steers the device.\n  Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n    1. Fredkin is too close to known heralded\u2010gate literature.\n    2. Quantum switch of swap orders is novel but closely related to published \u201ccoherent routing\u201d proposals.\n    3. The teleportation-router is wholly absent from the explored list, focuses on teleportation (not just swapping), and leverages near-field scattering as the central measurement device. Pytheus can optimize Bell-measurement networks via linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 3: Select the teleportation-router idea.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment designs a device that, in a single near-field multiport, chooses between two Bell-measurements on an unknown qubit and two EPR halves\u2014enabling a teleportation channel whose destination (Bob or Charlie) can itself be put into superposition.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only:\n    \u2022 one single-photon emitter (the unknown qubit)  \n    \u2022 two probabilistic Bell-pair sources  \n    \u2022 an optional single-photon ancilla to coherently steer the scatterer  \n    \u2022 a linear-optics multiport and number-resolving detectors  \n  This meets all constraints\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, pure network transformation (teleportation).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near\u2010Field Multiport\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown single-photon qubit from Alice (mode 0) either to Bob (mode B) or to Charlie (mode C), and\u2014even more powerfully\u2014in a coherent superposition of those two teleportation channels.  The core is a small \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d (a programmable linear-optical multiport) that implements two Bell measurements in an interferometric, near-field distribution of modes.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitter E\u2080 \u2192 unknown input (mode 0)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013B \u2192 modes A (1) & B (4)  \n \u2022 Pre-entangled Bell pair S_A\u2013C \u2192 modes A\u2032 (2) & C (5)  \n \u2022 Optional single-photon ancilla E\u2081 prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode \u03b1 (3)  \n\nAll six (or seven, with ancilla) photons enter a 7\u00d77 linear-optics multiport (\u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d) whose internal beam-splitters and phase-shifters distribute the near-field intensity pattern across output detectors.\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2080, D\u2081, D\u2082 at three designated output ports carry the teleported qubit (onto B or C) and record the ancilla.  \n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2084, D\u2085, D\u2086 herald the success of the two Bell measurements (one on modes {0,1}, one on {0,2}) by clicking in the correct pattern (one photon each).\n\nProtocol:\n 1. The scatterer mixes modes {0,1,2,3} so that, conditioned on D\u2083\u2026D\u2086 = {1,1,1,1}, it projects either {0+1} or {0+2} into a Bell basis\u2014chosen coherently by the ancilla\u2019s path in superposition.  \n 2. A successful click pattern signals that the unknown qubit has been teleported to mode B (4) or C (5), and the ancilla\u2019s state is entangled with which destination was used:\n      (|teleported\u2192B\u27e9|\u03b1=0\u27e9 + |teleported\u2192C\u27e9|\u03b1=1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n 3. By measuring the ancilla, one can collapse to a chosen receiver; by leaving it unmeasured, one obtains a genuine superposition of teleportation channels.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n  \u201cdescription\u201d: \u201cSuperposed Teleportation Router via Near-Field Multiport\u201d  \n  \u201csingle_emitters\u201d: [0,3]             # modes 0 (input) & 3 (ancilla)  \n  \u201cnum_pre\u201d: 2                         # two Bell-pair sources  \n  \u201cin_nodes\u201d: [0,1,2,3]                # unknown + two pair halves + ancilla  \n  \u201cout_nodes\u201d: [4,5]                   # Bob\u2019s mode=4, Charlie\u2019s=5  \n  \u201cnum_anc\u201d: 4                         # detectors at 3,4,5,6 for heralding  \n  \u201cremoved_connections\u201d: [              # forbid direct ancilla/pair\u2192wrong outputs  \n    [3,4],[3,5],[1,5],[2,4]  \n  ]  \n  \u201cnumber_resolving\u201d: True  \n  \u201ctarget_transformation\u201d:              # input\u2013output mapping for teleportation  \n    { \u201c00\u21924\u201d, \u201c01\u21924\u201d, \u201c10\u21925\u201d, \u201c11\u21925\u201d }  \n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell-pair sources and ancilla in higher-dimensional superposition, one can build a multi-destination quantum router that coherently splits and teleports an unknown qubit among N nodes\u2014all via the same near-field scattering device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the existing superposed\u2010teleportation router primitive. A and B (modes 0 and 1) enter a linear-optical \u201cnear-field scatterer\u201d together with two Bell-pair ancilla sources. The multiport implements two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014(0,2) and (1,4)\u2014heralded by four detectors. Conditioned on one photon per heralding detector, qubit A emerges at mode 5 (Bob\u2019s output) and qubit B at mode 3 (Alice\u2019s output), achieving reciprocal teleportation.\n\nSources:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters:  \n   \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n   \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 unknown qubit B (mode 1)  \n \u2022 Probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2013 S\u2082\u2083 \u2192 ancilla modes 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 S\u2084\u2085 \u2192 ancilla modes 4 & 5  \n\nAll six photons are fed into a 6\u00d76 linear-optical multiport (the near-field scatterer). At its outputs:\n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 D\u2083, D\u2085 are the two teleported outputs:  \n   \u2013 D\u2083 carries teleported qubit B (to Alice)  \n   \u2013 D\u2085 carries teleported qubit A (to Bob)  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 (modes 6\u20139) each resolve one photon from the ancilla Bell measurements.\n\nProtocol:\n \u2022 The scatterer mixes modes {0,2,1,4} so that, when D\u2086\u2026D\u2089 all click once, it projects (0,2) and (1,4) into Bell bases.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on {D\u2086\u2026D\u2089} = {1,1,1,1} heralds successful teleportation.  \n \u2022 Output ports 3 and 5 then carry the two teleported qubits, completing bidirectional teleportation in one shot.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation via near-field multiport\",\n  \"foldername\": \"bi_dir_tele\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\": [[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"in_nodes\": [0,1,2,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[2,3],[2,5],[3,5],[4,3],[4,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // A \u2192 Bob\n    \"1\u21923\"   // B \u2192 Alice\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more Bell pairs and unknown qubits, one can build an N\u21c4N simultaneous teleportation mesh via a single near-field scatterer\u2014opening a new class of multiplexed quantum-internet primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your protocol duplicates the existing \u201cbutterfly\u201d cross-teleportation primitive. A tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement\u2014realized by a near\u2010field scattering multiport\u2014that can be adjusted to project two photons onto the family of states {cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,\u2026}, enabling entanglement concentration on remote qubit pairs.\n    2. A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010purification step: two qutrit pairs entangled with noise are fed into a near\u2010field scatterer that implements a partial\u2010swap measurement, distilling one higher\u2010fidelity qutrit pair.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration is absent from the explored list; it\u2019s a network operation (entanglement distillation), not state generation. Qutrit purification is a natural generalization of (1) but more ambitious; better to start with qubits.\n  Step 3: Pick the tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment implements a continuously tunable Bell\u2010basis measurement via shaping a near\u2010field multiport scattering matrix\u2014and uses it to concentrate entanglement between two distant qubits.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (modes A\u2013B and C\u2013D).  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d whose internal beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases encode \u03b8.  \n    \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors for the central measurement.  \n  No cavities, no dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear\u2010optics network.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cTunable Near\u2010Field Partial\u2010Bell Measurement for Entanglement Concentration\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs:\n \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair between modes A (0) and B (1).\n \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair between modes C (2) and D (3).\n\nPhotons B (1) and C (2) are sent into a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport\u2014that we call the \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer.\u201d  The scatterer\u2019s internal beam\u2010splitter reflectivities and phase\u2010shifts are parametrized by \u03b8.  Outputs of the scatterer feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  Photons at A (0) and D (3) exit untouched to Alice and Bob, respectively.\n\nProtocol:\n 1. By tuning \u03b8, the scatterer implements a projection of modes (1,2) onto the two\u2010qubit basis  \n    {\u2009cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9+sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  sin\u2009\u03b8\u2009|00\u27e9\u2013cos\u2009\u03b8\u2009|11\u27e9,  |01\u27e9,  |10\u27e9\u2009}.  \n 2. Conditioned on the four detectors each clicking once, Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 3) collapse into a pure entangled state whose concurrence increases with \u03b8\u2014achieving entanglement concentration.\n 3. By sweeping \u03b8 from 0 to \u03c0/4, one interpolates continuously between no\u2010distillation and maximal\u2010distillation Bell\u2010measurement.\n\nVisualization:\n Sources:    [S\u2081:0\u20131]   [S\u2082:2\u20133]  \n                \u2193         \u2193  \n           Near\u2010field Scatterer (4\u00d74 multiport)  \n                \u2193  \u2193  \u2193  \u2193   \n          Detectors [D\u2081][D\u2082][D\u2083][D\u2084]  \n                \u2193  \n  Outputs: A (mode 0) \u2192 Alice,  D (mode 3) \u2192 Bob  \n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Tunable partial\u2010Bell measurement for entanglement concentration\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"partial_bell_conc\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement_basis\": [\n    \"cos\u03b8\u00b700+sin\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"sin\u03b8\u00b700\u2212cos\u03b8\u00b711\", \n    \"01\", \n    \"10\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Higher\u2010dimensional partial\u2010Bell measurements for qutrit or qudit entanglement concentration.  \n \u2022 Cascaded near\u2010field scatterers for multi\u2010round distillation in a quantum repeater chain.  \n \u2022 Real\u2010time tuning of \u03b8 to optimize concentration success\u2010rate vs. fidelity trade\u2010off.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014entanglement concentration via a tunable near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is new, parameterized, and well within the capabilities of Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement concentration by a tunable Bell measurement is a known protocol (Bennett\u2019s Procrustean method). Partial Bell concentration is known (Procrustean method) and reduces to a parameter sweep of Bell\u2010analyzer settings\u2014no new primitive.\n    2. Superposed swaps have appeared in proposals (\u201ccoherent routing of swap orders\u201d).\n    3. Quantum network coding (butterfly) for photonic networks hasn\u2019t been demonstrated in linear\u2010optics, and uses near\u2010field scattering to implement the key joint measurement at the bottleneck router. Pytheus can design ancilla\u2010assisted multiport measurements, so this is feasible.\n  Step 3: Select idea #3.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus\u2010generated experiment realizes the quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d network coding primitive via a single near\u2010field multiport measurement at the central router\u2014simultaneously enabling two cross\u2010teleportations through a shared channel.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it uses only:\n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (unknown qubits at nodes A and C),  \n    \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources (edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, C\u2013X),  \n    \u2022 A 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical \u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d at router X,  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding the joint measurement,  \n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014pure linear optics and post\u2010selection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cButterfly Quantum Network Coding via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe demonstrate the photonic version of the \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network code. Two senders, Alice (node A) and Charlie (node C), each hold an unknown qubit they wish to teleport crosswise: A\u2192D and C\u2192B. The network has a bottleneck link at router X that can carry only one qubit at a time. By pre\u2010sharing four EPR pairs on edges A\u2013B, C\u2013D, A\u2013X, and C\u2013X, and having router X perform a joint near\u2010field scattering measurement on its two incoming \u201cpacket\u201d qubits plus its two ancilla halves, we can effectively \u201ccode\u201d the qubits through the single bottleneck and achieve both teleportations simultaneously.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters:  \n    \u2013 E\u2080 \u2192 Alice\u2019s unknown qubit A (mode 0)  \n    \u2013 E\u2081 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s unknown qubit C (mode 1)  \n \u2022 EPR/PFF sources (probabilistic pairs):  \n    \u2013 S_AB \u2192 modes 2 (A\u2013B half) & 3 (B)  \n    \u2013 S_CD \u2192 modes 4 (C\u2013D half) & 5 (D)  \n    \u2013 S_AX \u2192 modes 6 (A\u2013X half) & 7 (X ancilla 1)  \n    \u2013 S_CX \u2192 modes 8 (C\u2013X half) & 9 (X ancilla 2)  \n\nProcedure:\n1. Node X collects four photons: mode 7, mode 9 (ancilla halves) and the two \u201cpacket\u201d qubits forwarded from A (mode 0) and C (mode 1).  \n2. These four photons enter a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d) whose beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases are optimized to perform the joint Bell\u2010like network\u2010coding measurement in one shot.  \n3. The multiport outputs feed four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2087\u2026D\u2081\u2080. A successful joint\u2010click pattern {1,1,1,1} heralds that node X has effectively performed the \u201cXOR\u201d\u2010type measurement required by quantum network coding.  \n4. Simultaneously, Alice and Charlie\u2019s distant EPR halves at modes 3 and 5 hold the teleported qubits:  \n     \u2013 mode 3 (Bob\u2019s location) now carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit C,  \n     \u2013 mode 5 (David\u2019s location) now carries Alice\u2019s original qubit A.  \n5. Classical broadcast of X\u2019s detector outcomes completes the Pauli correction at B and D.\n\nVisualization:\n  Single\u2010Emitters: [0:A][1:C]  \n  Bell\u2010Pairs: [2\u20133:A\u2192B]  [4\u20135:C\u2192D]  [6\u20137:A\u2192X]  [8\u20139:C\u2192X]  \n           \u2193  \n      Near\u2010Field Scatterer @ X (modes 0,1,7,9)  \n           \u2193  \n    Heralding Detectors [D\u2087][D\u2088][D\u2089][D\u2081\u2080]  \n           \u2193  \n    Outputs:  [3:B\u2190C]  [5:D\u2190A]\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Butterfly network coding via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"quantum_butterfly\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"pair_sources\":    [[2,3],[4,5],[6,7],[8,9]],\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"in_nodes\":       [0,1,7,9],\n  \"out_nodes\":      [3,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [7,3],[7,5],[9,3],[9,5]    // ancilla halves must go only into router X\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": {\n    \"0\u21925\",  // Alice\u2192David\n    \"1\u21923\"   // Charlie\u2192Bob\n  }\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-pair \u201cquantum network\u2010coding\u201d layouts by stacking near\u2010field scatterers across multiple bottlenecks.  \n\u2022 Replace EPR pairs with higher\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010pairs to code qudits through shared links.  \n\u2022 Integrate purification\u2010swap operations at intermediate nodes for repeater\u2010style fault tolerance.\n\nThis network coding primitive\u2014enabled by a near\u2010field multiport measurement\u2014is a new quantum\u2010network transformation well within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla-photon, and number\u2010resolving capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the known photonic butterfly network coding implementations. Two noisy Bell\u2010pairs (S\u2081 between A\u2013X, S\u2082 between X\u2013B) arrive at X on modes 1 and 2 (the \u201csignal halves\u201d). An ancilla Bell\u2010pair S\u2083 on modes 3\u20134 provides the resource photons for both the parity check and the subsequent Bell projection. All four photons (modes 1,2,3,4) enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics multiport (\u201cnear\u2010field scatterer\u201d). The near\u2010field distribution of internal interference patterns (beam\u2010splitters & phase shifts) is optimized so that:\n\n  Step A (Parity Check): Conditioned on a specific two\u2010click pattern in detectors D\u2085 and D\u2086, the parity of modes 1 and 2 is measured, projecting them onto the even\u2010parity subspace and thus purifying the remaining halves at A and B.  \n  Step B (Swap): Simultaneously, the same interferometric network routes the purified qubit halves through an effective Bell\u2010measurement (on the purified ancilla halves) and heralds a successful entanglement swap between A and B via detectors D\u2087 and D\u2088.\n\nWhen all four heralding detectors (D\u2085\u2026D\u2088) click once each, node X has effectively performed purification\u2009+\u2009swapping in one shot, delivering a higher\u2010fidelity entangled link between A and B (modes 0 and 5).\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0:A, 1:X\u2081]  \n \u2022 Pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2:X\u2082, 3:B]  \n \u2022 Ancilla pair   S\u2083 \u2192 modes [4:X\u2083, 5:X\u2084]  \n\nAll four X\u2010modes [1,2,4,5] are fed into the 4\u00d74 near\u2010field scatterer. Outputs:\n \u2022 Logical outputs: mode 0 (A) unchanged, mode 3 (B) unchanged.  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors: D\u2085\u2026D\u2088 on the four scatterer outputs.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Integrated entanglement purification + swap via near-field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":  \"purify_swap_scatter\",\n  \"pair_sources\": [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"num_anc\":       4,\n  \"in_nodes\":     [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\":    [0,3],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [4,0],[4,3],[5,0],[5,3]  // ancilla halves only go into scatterer\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_measurement\": [\n    \"parity_check(1,2) \u2192 detectors D5,D6\",\n    \"bell_proj(remaining_modes) \u2192 detectors D7,D8\"\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to three or more pairs: fuse multi\u2010round purification + multi\u2010node swapping in one multiport.  \n\u2022 Replace the ancilla Bell\u2010pair with multiple ancilla pairs for higher\u2010order distillation.  \n\u2022 Adapt to d\u2010dimensional qudits by increasing the scatterer size\u2014yielding one\u2010shot purification/swapping for cluster\u2010state repeaters.\n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrating purification and swapping in a single near\u2010field scattering measurement\u2014is a new repeater primitive tailor\u2010made for Pytheus\u2019s ancilla\u2010assisted multiport design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the existing single-shot purification+swap repeater primitive. A single near\u2010field multiport that fuses entanglement purification and swapping in one shot (we saw this merges known steps).\n    2. A near\u2010field\u2013based programmable entanglement router (entanglement switch) for N nodes (edges toward quantum switch).\n    3. An indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order network: superpose two entanglement\u2010swapping operations that share a qubit\u2014using an ancilla\u2010steered near\u2010field scatterer\u2014so that the swap order itself is put into quantum superposition.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    1. Purification+swap is known.\n    2. General entanglement router edges too close to quantum switch literature.\n    3. Indefinite causal order of two non\u2010commuting swap operations is a new network primitive; it uses only linear optics, probabilistic pairs, a single\u2010photon ancilla, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 3.\n  Step 4: It\u2019s novel because no existing Pytheus design or published linear\u2010optics experiment superposes the order of two entanglement\u2010swapping operations acting on overlapping qubits. This would be the first \u201cquantum switch\u201d of entanglement\u2010swapping, probing non\u2010commutativity in a network context.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it requires:\n    \u2022 Three EPR/pair sources to create pairs AB, BC, and CD  \n    \u2022 One single\u2010photon ancilla emitter in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 to steer the sequence  \n    \u2022 A 5\u00d75 \u201cnear\u2010field\u201d linear\u2010optics multiport (beam splitters & phases) that, conditional on the ancilla, implements either the B\u2013C Bell measurement first then C\u2013D, or vice versa  \n    \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding each Bell measurement  \n  No cavities or dynamic feedback are needed, and we target a network transformation (indefinite\u2010order swap), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment\u2014\u201cIndefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping via Near\u2010Field Scatterer\u201d:\n\nDescription:\nWe want to entangle qubit A (mode 0) and qubit D (mode 5) by performing two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping operations on three pre\u2010shared EPR pairs: AB, BC, and CD. Crucially, we place the order of the two Bell\u2010measurements (on pairs BC and CD) into quantum superposition, thus realizing an indefinite causal order of network operations.\n\nSources & Modes:\n \u2022 Pair source S_AB \u2192 modes [0:A, 1:B]  \n \u2022 Pair source S_BC \u2192 modes [2:B\u2032, 3:C]  \n \u2022 Pair source S_CD \u2192 modes [4:C\u2032, 5:D]  \n \u2022 Single\u2010photon ancilla emitter E_ctrl prepared in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 mode 6\n\nAll seven photons (modes 1,2,3,4,6) plus the unchanged modes 0 and 5 are directed into a 5\u00d75 near\u2010field multiport (programmable beam splitters & phase shifters).  The ancilla photon\u2019s path controls the internal routing:\n\n  \u2022 If ancilla is |0\u27e9 \u2192 perform Bell\u2010measurement on (modes 2,3) first (swap BC), feed the outcome into the next stage to measure (modes 4,? depending on scatterer), then swap CD.  \n  \u2022 If ancilla is |1\u27e9 \u2192 reverse the order: swap CD first, then BC.  \n\nDetectors:\n \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084 monitor the two Bell\u2010measurements\u2019 outputs.  \n \u2022 Detection pattern {1,1,1,1} (one click each) heralds success.  \n\nProtocol & Target Transformation:\n \u2022 Conditioned on ancilla measured in the |+\u27e9\u2010basis and the 4\u2010click herald, the final state of modes 0 (A) and 5 (D) is  \n    (|\u03a8_swap-BC-then-CD\u27e9 + |\u03a8_swap-CD-then-BC\u27e9)/\u221a2,  \n  a coherent superposition of the two entanglement\u2010routing orders.  \n \u2022 Because the two swap operations share qubit C, they do not commute; this yields an observable interference effect on the A\u2013D entanglement fidelity as a function of an inserted phase between operations\u2014a direct test of non\u2010commuting network processes.\n\nPytheus Config Pointers:\n{\n  \"description\":   \"Indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping via near\u2010field scatterer\",\n  \"foldername\":    \"swapping_quantum_switch\",\n  \"pair_sources\":  [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]],\n  \"single_emitters\": [6],\n  \"num_anc\":        4,\n  \"in_nodes\":      [1,2,3,4,6],\n  \"out_nodes\":     [0,5],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n     [6,0],[6,5]   // ancilla must only enter the multiport\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"target_transformation\": \"superpose_order_of_swaps(BC,CD)\"\n}\n\nGeneralization:\nBy adding more EPR\u2010pairs and higher\u2010dim ancilla controls, one can create N\u2010switch networks of M sequential swaps, directly exploring multi\u2010order causal superpositions in complex quantum\u2010internet primitives. This opens a new research direction in indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order quantum networks.\n\nThis is a brand\u2010new network primitive\u2014an entanglement\u2010swapping quantum switch\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics, ancilla\u2010photon, and post\u2010selection toolkit, and it promises a Phys. Rev. Lett.\u2013level theory paper on network causal non\u2010separability in quantum optics."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. By post-selecting on a fixed pattern of Bell outcomes and contrasting clockwise versus counterclockwise traversal, we directly reveal a non-commuting (non-Abelian) Wilson-loop effect in a purely linear-optical quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes.
